The Respondent further undertook, in the event that assignment proved “impossible” to make payment to the Petitioner of such sum as is held in the policy “at a time to be agreed between the parties”.

In the statement in support of her application, the Applicant asserts that the Respondent has “stalled on implementation” and invites the court to “enforce assignment” or “facilitate a cash payment in lieu of transfer”. As I have already noted, in his statement the Respondent asserts, within the context of his undertaking to take all necessary steps to assign “as soon as possible” his interest in the Zurich Policy, that immediately following the order of 13 October 2011 he provided a letter of authority to Mr L permitting him to liaise directly with Zurich but was informed by Mr L on 15 February 2015 that it was not possible to assign the benefit of the policy to the Applicant.

Within the foregoing context, the Respondent undertook before Deputy District Judge Butler on 1 March 2016 to provide Mr L with a power of attorney to enable the policy to be cashed in and the funds (net of tax) paid to the Applicant. The evidence before the court indicates that the Respondent attempted to comply with that undertaking but was not able to do so for the reasons set out in Paragraph 16 above. Namely, Mr L’s position that only the Respondent can surrender the policy in circumstances where a Jersey based company will not accept a power of attorney given in the United Kingdom, that Mr L could not deal with the potential tax position of the surrender proceeds and that there would be a conflict of interest in the Applicant’s financial advisers acting for the Respondent.

In circumstances where it would appear that the assignment to the Applicant of the policy is “impossible” for the purposes of the order of 13 October 2011, the provisions for payment of the net value of the policy by the Respondent to the Applicant on a date to be agreed between the parties become operative. Both parties accept that, whilst the Respondent undertook on 1 March 2016 to provide a power of attorney to enable the policy to be cashed in and the resulting funds (net of tax) paid to the Applicant, no time for payment of such sum as is held in the policy in lieu of assignment of the policy to the Applicant has yet been agreed between them pursuant to order of 13 October 2011. In the absence of such an agreement it cannot in my judgment be said that the Respondent is yet in default of this provision.

The Respondent accepts that he remains liable to the Applicant under the terms of the order that deal with the Zurich policy. The assignment to the Applicant of the policy being apparently “impossible” for the purposes of the order of 13 October 2011, the Respondent is now required by the terms of his undertaking to pay to the Applicant such sum as is held within the Zurich policy on date to be agreed between the parties. Such a date not yet having been agreed between the parties, in the circumstances it seems to me that the appropriate order is an order adjourning the Applicant’s application to enforce the term concerning the Zurich Policy to allow the parties a period of time to agree, pursuant to the terms of the order of 13 October 2011, the date by which the Respondent will pay to the Applicant such sum as is held within the Zurich policy (in contradistinction to the payment of a fixed sum of £129,083 proposed by the Respondent) and for payment to be made by that agreed date. In the event that the Respondent refuses to agree a date or fails by the date agreed to make payment to the Applicant of such sum as is held within the Zurich policy and is thereby in default, then the Applicant’s application to enforce can be reinstated.
CONCLUSION

For the reasons I have given, I stay the Applicant’s application to enforce the provisions of the order of 13 October 2011 relating to maintenance and I adjourn the Applicant’s application to enforce the provisions of the order relating to the Zurich policy generally with liberty to restore. As I have already noted, the Applicant does not seek to pursue the other aspects of her application for enforcement and those parts of her application will stand dismissed. Having regard the position on costs indicated by the Respondent in response to the Applicant’s concession with respect to the enforcement of the provisions of the 2011 order relating to the investment funds, there will be no order as to costs. I will invite the parties to agree and submit an order incorporating these decisions.
That is my judgment.
